item.title: Don't Kill the Messenger
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
These stories leave me speechless.
Here I'll just post the news with minimal commentary.
When a cyclist dies, here's the investigation:
"According to police, the drivers and many witnesses stopped and provided statements. Still, police are asking for the public's help. "If anyone did see what happen though or may have been here during the accident and wants to give up some information, please call the police department. We'd be glad to talk to you.," said Lt. Jerry Hara with the San Diego Police Department."
http://www.sandiego6.com/news/local/Bicyclist-Killed-by-Several-Cars-in-Clairemont-143867526.html
Got that. We'll just sit around and wait for the phone to ring with "information". Thanks.
San Diego’s lieutenant of Traffic Division Rick O’Hanlon said, “it is not the police department’s decision to file charges. Even if we make a custodial arrest, the City Attorney has within their latitude to dismiss the charges.”
http://www.gjel.com/blog/san-diego-police-say-in-cyclist-vehicle-accidents-stiffest-charges-are-traffic-violations.html
When an office dies:
"Today is a difficult day for all people who serve in San Diego's finest," said the chief, who called the shooting an "assassination."
http://www.kpbs.org/news/2011/aug/07/san-diego-police-shot-critically-hurt-suspect-dead/
Got that? A cyclist's death is a traffic incident where they aren't even sure whether they are able to file charges, but a police officer's death is an "assasination."
It gets better. Next, the police sat around by their phone waiting for someone to call right?
Haha.
"At about 6 p.m., police found the Audi outside some apartments in the 4000 block of 48th Street. Collins said a police helicopter directed ground units to the 48th Street address as the suspect with the shotgun got back into the Audi. Police blocked the street in an attempt to stop the car, but the suspect allegedly grabbed the shotgun and was fired upon by multiple officers."
Well, while they do nothing, that can be a form of malignant neglect, but they aren't running people over, are they?
"Nationally, 123 people died in 2009 from crashes involving a police vehicle, but only 33 deaths happened when blue lights and sirens were on for an emergency response, federal figures show."
"Georgia counted 2,422 crashes involving police vehicles in 2011, and police were likely at fault in nearly 1,400, numbers from the Georgia Department of Transportation show. Of those crashes, 533 resulted in injury and more than half were likely caused by the police vehicle." But at least they're sorry, right?
"In fatality crashes for the year, two of the three deaths were likely the fault of the civilian vehicle involved, GDOT indicated...police say officers are often the ones hurt by drivers who aren't paying attention to the road or don't hear the sirens blaring."
Get it? If you get hit by a speeding officer, it's your fault for not getting out of the way.

item.title: Honesty in Advocacy
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
This is going to be a more of an overview of my feelings on advocacy rather than advocacy itself.
To be fair, let's not that I'm NOT an advocate because I don't DO anything in the real world.
On the other hand, I am a sideline cheerleader, idea person, statistics analyzer, fact checker, and comedian.
I struggle to be as honest as possible. When speaking about safety of modes, I was told that I shouldn't speak of the dangers of cycling because that doesn't promote cycling.
Well guess what, I really do think that honesty is best.
However, I am noticing a lack of dishonesty in many cases with cycling advocacy.
I have beaten the VC issue to death, but it bears mention here that they are really concerned with racers and speed rather than absolute safety.
Then there's the helmet debate with intelligent (mainly) cyclists getting in bed with cyclists haters in order to convince us that we'll all be "organ donors" unless we ride with a plastic colander on our heads at all times. Yes, the cyclists want to prevent the massive head injuries from getting hit by cars, oops I'm sorry, I meant minor scrapes on the noggin from solo falls. They are honest. But the anti-cyclists are totally dishonest.
There's much more. You usually find dishonesty cloaked in the form of righteousness such as calling cyclists arrogant as if this were a sin. There's also the cloak of vague and academic language which tries to win the debate by mystification.
Sorry, if you can't tell it to a nine year old, I'm not going to parse it.
There's also the cloak of making up our own language. Again, I will read the words to mean how I know they are. If I need a glossary, I am not interested.
What I want most of all from all of us, cyclists and non-cyclists is to really, really honest with ourselves.
Do cyclists really cause that much harm or do we just hate cyclists and want them harassed by cops?
Are helmets really that helpful or harmful?
Are bike paths really a deadly disease?
If sidewalk and alley riding so deadly why to parents, even VCers, train their kids there instead of the "safe" travel lane on a shroad?
Do we really give a shit about safety or do we really just want to ride fast?
I don't wish to hear the answers, I just want people to be honest with themselves first. You can later on go out there and lie to all of us.
But please don't bullshit yourself; there's no reason for it.

item.title: Incompetents Should Not Drive the Discussion
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
It seems that since we think that everyone's opinion is equal, we should listen to everyone about every topic not matter how incompetent the person professes to be.
In fact, it seems that not only are people incompetent, but they are proud of this incompetence and they brag about it.
For example, when we talk about putting in bicycle lanes, we hear stuff like "nobody rides their bicycle on this street."
This is clearly wrong, but the deeper issue is that when we hear things like this, it's a red flag that the person is totally incompetent when it comes to judging the need for infrastructure. This incompetence is compounded when we learn that they are also not regular bicycle riders. Some of them think that one can not possibly ride a bicycle to work and that my morning commute which I ride daily to feed my family is a worthless hobby. Well, after this, why don't we educate these people or at least shut them out of the discussion until they educate themselves? This is not an equal opinion we are talking about but a total lack of touch with reality.
Things get better when we hear people say, "I can't possibly live my life without a car."
OK, great, you're a big man to admit your personal weaknesses and limitations, but this should be last thing we listen to regarding cycling from this person. These people like to go on and on about how dangerous cyclists are, but how do they know that when they admit that they can't even imagine riding their bicycle to work. This is strange because I can imagine myself jumping over the moon and eating it's delicious green cheese. While I know that these things are impossible, at least I can _imagine_ it. With limited imagination come solutions which only look like the past.
And if the past design is so great, why are we talking about it as if there is a problem now? So clearly things were done badly in the past, and we need to imagine a better future.
Let's not sacrifice a bold vision on the altar of the incompetent!

item.title: Lack of Active Transportation Dooms Millions to Pain
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
http://www.alternet.org/food/guess-whos-behind-new-findings-its-healthy-be-overweight?paging=off
I really loved this story especially this bit:
”While some people who lose weight do keep it off, she says they are as rare as people who win the lottery. “OK, they exist,” she says, “But if I'm a health care provider, if I know that 98% of the people I send down this road will end up sicker, physically and psychologically, why would I do that?”
Yes, but we should take into account our built environment which kind of sucks for building exercise into one's life.
This is probably said too many times here, but you can't really hold people accountable for their exercise when they can't do it safely. This is why I think that we should have more cycling infrastructure, as a public health concern.
More important than worrying about whether the right BMI for women is 27.3 or 25, the more important thing is for them to get some fitness into their lives.
Also, as I stated before, I do not think that making and selling junk food should be legal. It serves no purpose other than to make many, many people fat and a few of them rich. Hurting the public is a dubious freedom at best: the freedom to eat absolute trash which only leaves you broke, hungry, and fat is one in which I could do without.
This excellent podcast elaborates on these notions:
http://c-realm.com/podcasts/03-michael-goodwin-how-did-the-richest-country-in-the-world-come-to-eat-such-cruddy-food/
What about the freedom to build exercise into your commute? Is this not more important?
For me this is a big shift in thinking, too: the whole notion of fitness vs. athletics.
http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/03/education/spelman-college-withdrawing-from-ncaa.html?_r=0
“When we studied this early this year, I was startled to see that we really had only 80 student athletes out of 2,100 students, and our program was costing almost $1 million,” said Beverly Daniel Tatum, the college president. “I was also surprised to learn of studies showing that African-American women are the least physically active demographic in the U.S.”
For me, this is a really tough topic because for the longest time I had felt that I didn't like to exercise and I definitely did not value fitness. I realize that while I still eschew cycling racing, I do feel a great deal of gratitude for my good fortune to have excise as part of my commute.
However, I do feel that my fortune is due to luck, and if I were from San Diego, I would probably not be a cycling commuter.
I think that we should follow the bold lead of Spelman and to indulge ourselves in the luxury of active transportation. After all, this would cost much less than the luxury we all ready have of being fat and unhealthy.

item.title: Tax Payer Douche Cycling
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
I probably said this before, but I'll say it again, I can't stand selfish people who whine about their "gas money" and "tax money" because the ones that whine the most are those who benefit the most from the others.
Thus, I, too, would like everything to be perfectly fair which would mean that I owe a lot of people around the world some time in sewing and fruit picking.
The tax foundation posted a study which shows what share of roads are built with the so called "gas money" aka all motoring user fees.
http://taxfoundation.org/blog/road-spending-state-funded-user-taxes-and-fees-including-federal-gas-tax-revenues
California ranks at 34.4% which means that we spend three times too much for roads.
A good start for tax paying advocacy would be to demand that we cut our road budget in half.
We MUST do this if we are consistent and want to be 100% fair as can be.

item.title: Are Misleading Helmet Statements Illegal?
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
LTRs can skip this one.
One thing I hadn't thought of regarding the "helmets prevent 85% of injuries" claim for helmets is that this might actually be illegal.
http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/policystmt/ad-decept.htm
"Most deception involves written or oral misrepresentations, or omissions of material information...The issue is whether the act or practice is likely to mislead, rather than whether it causes actual deceptions."
Here's the claim: " In regression analyses to control for age, sex, income, education, cycling experience, and the severity of the accident, we found that riders with helmets had an 85 percent reduction in their risk of head injury (odds ratio, 0.15; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.07 to 0.29) and an 88 percent reduction in their risk of brain injury (odds ratio, 0.12; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.04 to 0.40)."
http://www.cyclehelmets.org/1068.html
Why is this misleading.
First of all, I'd like to quote the usual response to criticism of this paper, that I misunderstand odd ratios. This is true.
http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=3&ved=0CEIQFjAC&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sph.unc.edu%2Fimages%2Fstories%2Facademic_programs%2Fepid%2Fdocuments%2FQualifying_Exams%2FInjury%2FReadings%2Fcummings_2006.pdf&ei=kowmUajWO-XfigK0t4GQBg&usg=AFQjCNGB-2Xi4VGngFKALUbpnmTskkootw&sig2=s5v3TfFZ9eyPLzTi1QWW_Q&bvm=bv.42768644,d.cGE
I do not understand any of the stats at all.
I don't think I need to. The claim is clear. If 100% of the people wore helmets, then head injuries would be 85% less than if 0% of people wore helmets.
http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=4&cad=rja&ved=0CE4QFjAD&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.infrastructure.gov.au%2Froads%2Fsafety%2Fpublications%2F2006%2Fpdf%2Fdeath_cyclists_road.pdf&ei=t5EmUbfPLoeCiwKbjYFQ&usg=AFQjCNHm_FcC7FBK5xw88m3szn-0pzdeuQ&sig2=v6K-3eAgNtr0t-1HDA2snA&bvm=bv.42768644,d.cGE
Given this data, on page 5, it's easy to see that over 50% of cyclists who got hit by cars and died were hit at 50 Km or higher. The question is that, given the high number of fatalities and injury which occured by getting hit by a high speed car, which percentage of these people would have been saved if they were wearing helmets?

item.title: Another Motorists Chimes In: Sharing the Road Sucks
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
This is another repeat. Anther link bait story where I at first agree with then get pissed off as she blames me for all her problems. I have a tissue for my new friend, Melissa.
http://www.thegavoice.com/opinion/thats-what-she-said/5860-melissa-carter-cars-arent-the-problem-with-share-the-road
Cyclists often have a knee jerk reaction to the whole anti-share the road notion, but whole heartedly agree.
Like the child who cried that the Emperor had not clothing, Melissa Carter reveals the lameness that is the stupid, and failed "share the road" nonsense.
"I will honestly say that I do not believe in sharing the road. The weight of a car can be 4,000 pounds and a car can reach speeds well over 100 mph. In contrast, the average bicycle weighs about 30 pounds and an average rider can only go about 20 mph."
This is the voice of reason and is why we need our own space.
"But somehow we have decided that the way to coexist is to travel the same roads together in harmony."
If she only knew that there were a few morons out there who want this and that the vast majority of cyclists and motorists want our own space! (http://iamtraffic.org)
"However, the burden of traveling safely together ultimately depends on the driver slowing down, swerving over, etc., in an effort not to mortally wound this soul who is inching up a hill on Roswell Road during rush hour."
Yes, that's totally unfair. But it's also nice to see that this motorist realizes that it's luck in getting "good" drivers who let the VC DBs live and not some kind of superior skill.
"Often, I see a bicyclist merge into existing traffic and block a lane while holding his or her hand out impatiently for us to slow down as if we “car people” are the problem."
Ug, this sucks. I do it, but I have to in order to get to work. Still, like Melissa, I agree that this is non-optimal.
"And if you come up on a pack of riders, it is even worse since they have no problem riding side by side and taking up an entire lane."
Yes, I agree. I often actually ride in the parallel parking lane or pull over to let motorists go ahead. It's not because I feel inferior but because I have manners.
"Apparently, a jersey that has a logo or two on it along with the aerodynamic Tour de France helmet translates to some extra level of ownership of the asphalt. Sometimes they seem to be tempting someone to hit them."
I couldn't have said it better myself.
"It does not look like Atlanta will ever create enough bike paths to get cyclists off the main roads."
I disagree. I have no idea where she got this idea from. Why not push for more paths and be part of the solution to the problem that she is pointing out. Seems like she doesn't really want to solve the problem at this point. I can't prove it, but I think that this is because she doesn't want more bike paths. I hope I am wrong.
"But I do believe there is a solution that would at least make me feel like drivers and cyclists were being treated a little more fairly.
I want everyone who wants to put their bikes on the main road to get a license and a tag."
As I wrote earlier, she moved from having a legitimate complaint and she pin pointed the solution then she ignored the solution and moved to bullying tactics.
"To pay for the new bicycle-specific testing and the enforcement, the measure would have required a fee for the endorsement test and registration via a license plate for all bicycles in Oregon."
Why testing? What is this going to accomplish?
"By having license plates on the bikes, the hope is that this would lead to more responsible behavior and make it easier to hold riders accountable for their actions."
I assume that Melissa has a license plate, but she still managed to get off at least one veiled threat in a public article "they seem to be tempting someone to hit them."
I hope that she does not hit someone, but it seems almost as if she feels tempted (her words).
"At least if I were behind a cyclist with a license plate, I would know that my extra ten minutes in traffic were the result of some effort on the part of the rider and not just a flippant disregard for all the other tax paying citizens on the road who are doing their best to dodge them."
First of all, I call bullshit on the ten minutes.
Second, in most states motoring does not pay for the roads either. Plus most cyclists have cars so they paid for the road all ready. We also mostly all ready do have licenses.
Finally, I don't flippantly disregard other tax paying citizens (sic) as if paying taxes makes you a citizen (it does not). I don't want to be on the road, it's because motorists were too short sighted and cheap to build meaningful infrastructure as well as lame ass VC advocacy that came up with such nonsense such as "share the road" that is the cause of your misery.
"To truly share the road, we must all share the responsibility for being in each other’s path."
This just pissed me off.
Really, she's responsible for being in my way? I estimate that my time to work is double due to me waiting for cars. Furthermore, I have NEVER had, in a traffic jam, all the cars pull to the side to let me pass. I pull over daily when I can to let people pass.
This story is just there to inflame cyclists and motorists aka link bait. I'm guilty of taking the juicy bait. The entire post, except for her down home style, which I like, could have been written by a computer as it's the same stupid propaghanda. Cyclists cause ALL the problems on the roads. Cyclists are cheap ass moochers who are totally irresponsible and no doubt the cause of every traffic jam.
Ug.

item.title: Open Letter to BikeMD
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
One of the questions that has continued to plague us is the continual pushing for helmets as personal protection equipment (PPE) despite the fact that it is ineffective for the most common causes of death which is getting hit by a high speed motorist.
I feel very strongly about helmets because I believe that the promotion of helmets is a way of blaming the victim and is thus a pattern of abuse and bully behaviors that the motoring culture is continuing to inflict on the cycling community.
Since I do not live in Maryland, I am almost happy that this law is going to be passed because it enshrines in law what many organizations have all ready been advocating for. Also, it will give some decent data, in the United States that helmets are useless.
Thus, I have asked bikemd the following:
I am a blogger and I'm collecting information for a story about the mandatory helmet law (MLH) in MD for my blog, cyclingunbound.wordpress.com a San Diego, CA based cycling blog. I found your name in a recent article which I first saw on the WashCycle, and excellent blog.
I rode my bicycle through Maryland in 2008 and I was highly impressed diverse small towns, bicycle paths, and dedicated bicycle lanes on major arterials. Thus, I can only praise your organization for its successes in these regards.
I believe that advocacy should be data driven, and I am unafraid to confront any data which makes cycling more efficient, comfortable, and safer.
In no way do I feel that these questions are meant to be insulting, but I do wrestle with ethical issues myself and I appreciate any assistance that you can give while we all look at the difficult and sometimes dark side of advocacy.
Finally, I feel that someone must push the rhetoric so far that the most extreme demands by the local cycling advocacy groups look like they aren't asking for enough. This is my role so please bear that in mind.
1. How does your organization decide which public policy that your organization represents? By public policy, I mean which laws you are in favor of, against, and so on. I also mean, by public policy, which public works projects such as cycling infrastructure that your organization supports of fights.
1. Does your organization support helmet use? If so, what means do they feel that they should compel people to wear helmets?
2. Do you support a mandatory helmet law? If not, why not (in the case that you agree with #1)?
3. The helmet issue is so controversial, with people who are rabidly in favor of them as well as rabidly against them. Also there is literature which says that helmets will save 85% of all lives, while the demographic data in places where helmets are mandatory disagree. There are also many researchers who think that helmets are useless (see the British Medical Journal, for example). Given all this controversy, how does your organization come out with a coherent policy either in favor or against #1.
4. Do you feel that a mandatory helmet law is going to hurt or help the promotion of more people cycling or is the promotion of cycling to new people something your organization is not interested in?
5. If helmets save many lives and should always be worn while cycling and if helmets will hurt cycling, is there an ethical problem with failing to enshrine into law something that everyone should all ready do as it will save lives? Many CA advocates feel that helmets have saved their lives, but they refuse to stand for a MHL because they feel that it will hurt their cause--are not cyclists lives more important than the cause?

item.title: Sick of the Bullshit Cycling
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Let me re-iterate for the billionth time that my daily commute is nice, though, I realize that it should be harrowing.
I recently talked to two co-workers who told me that the main reason that they do not ride to work is due to the lack of a decent path from the top of the mesa down into Mission Valley. Fairmount Ave is a non-starter because they recognize that it is potentially deadly and always harrowing.
A co-worker of mine, last week, was shocked that both my wife and I did not use cars due to our "modern metropolis".
What he intuitively knew, but could not say, was that the reason for this is because cycling in San Diego totally sucks due to malignant neglect as well as the hard work of Quisling advocates who kept the government out of making cycling safe, while they allowed it to trod, willy-nilly, over safety.
To paraphrase one Quisling to Sandag, "I don't care what you do to the roads".
Asshole.
Here's another cyclist who realized that cycling actually sucks:
http://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/20130309/OPINION/130309607/1042/opinion?p=2&tc=pg
Note that no matter how safe he is or is not, he _feels_ like crap after cycling and that's what matters to most people. He isn't going to look up some stats to see how his day was.
After reading that, for cyclists, the death rate for commonly thought dangerous activities is 10% or less, I realized that stupid organizations like the NHTSA offer suggestions that are not only condescending, but even if followed to the letter would provide marginal safety at best.
"Over time, with riders being mowed down almost monthly, I became more vigilant. I always wore bright colors, used hand signals and anticipated the actions of unsafe drivers."
So I have some questions to the NHTSA:
1. Given that we do all that you say, such as wearing bright colors and helmets, since the vast majority of collisions are not do to anything on your list, when are you going to take safety to the next level. That is, after you get ALL PEDESTRIANS and CYCLISTS in your yellow jackets and plastic hats, and we are still dying, what's the next step?
2. The same can be said for motorists as well. If we get all the drunks and texters off the road, we STILL, STILL find that the majority of killer motorists did not violate any rules at all. If this is so, what's the next move for making the roads safer?
Or are we going to just all have to get into tanks and drive those?
Can we please, please just pull the plug on the NHTSA?

item.title: Cyprus Bailout Cycling
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Recently, when I read that the wealthy are literally taking from the poor, no more proxies, I realized that the same thing is happening indirectly regarding motoring.
http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/18/us-eurozone-cyprus-stumbled-insight-idUSBRE92H0RH20130318?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews&utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+reuters%2FtopNews+%28News+%2F+US+%2F+Top+News%29
The phrase that struck a chord in my mind was the notion of "burden sharing". That is, the bankers fucked up and now they want to dip into people's personal bank accounts, money that should be stuffing mattresses, to pay off their mistakes which were caused by incompetence and greed.
I find the whole notion, of pedestrians, especially having to "equally share the burden" of looking both ways before they cross the street to be similarly offensive.
Pedestrians created zero percent of the danger and now they are being billed with fifty percent of the responsibility.
Is this fair?
Surely this isn't a tax in money, but it is taxing to one's mental state as well as in terms of carnage which is disproportionately (again) born by pedestrians.
Motoring danger and police aiding and abetting with the get away.
Just another way we get ripped off.
The icing on the cake is when bikes and pedestrians as asked to "pay their fair share" as if put in constant mortal danger isn't enough of a price to pay.

item.title: My Commute VI
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Many days, on Ward Rd, I go totally VC and take the LEFT lane for many reasons.
1. I'm making a left turn.
2. Traffic behind me is light on the road.
3. There's a dangerous crest of a hill that blocks one's view until the last second, making this turn super dangerous.
4. Oncoming traffic is somewhat heavy.
5. There's a door zone in the right lane.
6. I said this before, but it bears repeating. People LOVE to hug the side of the road to the point of driving in the parallel parking lane, riding on half the should of the road to the point of always wanting to put their SUV in the gutter EVEN WHEN THERE ARE TWO LANES OR MORE WHICH ARE 90% CLEAR.
Why? I don't know.
But if people are going to be buzzing me while I ride in the door zone, I feel safer in the left lane especially when I barely get passed ever. Plus I tend to ride to the left of the left lane so that if someone does wish to get close, I can just go onto or over the double yellow line. In the door zone, there's no where to do except into a door.
Sometimes, if there is heavy traffic behind me, I will ride in door zone. The other bonus of riding in right lane is that I am closer to bus stop where they often smile back at me right before I cross over 4 lanes of a high speed road.
Once I make this turn, once again, I have another respite and a sigh or relief.

item.title: Cycling for Networking
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Like all normal people, I find the whole notion of networking to be repugnant. It seems so manipulative to meet people only to use them for one's own benefit.
On the other hand, like most other people, in order to get anything done in my actual life, I do need to meet people.
I got my job through a great friend that I met at a party. Another good friend, I met through a friend through a writing group. And so on.
So meeting people is great, but tactically trying to network sucks.
The way out is to meet in groups for people with shared interests.
Group bicycle rides are an excellent way to meet people.
I have said this for so long, it's practically a cliche, but I love to see a shiny pickup truck full of dudes who are yelling at me and my friends on a group ride about why am I doing it?
One of my friends always says, "cancer".
The funny thing is that these truck dudes are definitely looking to score. They pass by a horde of beautiful women on bicycles and all they can do is shout crude stuff.
The majority of my social life in San Diego has been through cycling. I think that group rides are also a great way for beginners to learn how to navigate the city.
For shy people, it's great because you are doing something so you are not just trapped talking to someone or worse sitting alone. People are more approachable when it's bicycle to bicycle.
I have even had a few nice chats while commuting to work or going home with someone I met while we rode the same way.

item.title: Penny Farthing
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Last weekend, I met my first Penny Farthing rider, and he made an even huger impression on me than recumbent riders.
Before I go on, I'd like to say that I only met this guy once, but I can't identify him because he wore a Nixon mask the whole time--or he was Nixon.
Also, he disguised his voice.
Finally, the whole account below is totally fictional.
Did you ever meet a twisted, looking glass version of yourself if you had stayed on the "bad" course in your life?
I did and his name is P. Farthing.
A Penny Farthing bicycle is one of the oldest bikes which has no chain, no gears, and no brakes. It's basically a giant wheel with pedals and a seat attached.
Though illustrations of Penny Farthings make them look like sissies, this is actually the badest ass bike ever; a tank of the bicycle world.
It can do pretty much everything I want a bicycle to do and some things I won't admit to wanting.
For example, it never gets flats. It's super easy to coast. And if it runs into a car door, by accident, it rips the door off!
It sits so high off the ground that if you get cut off and step off the bicycle you wind up standing on the hood of a car.
With no brakes, stopping is a gradual foot dragging process.
The rider seemed a combination of mania, intensity, and joy that I seldom see. For the first time, I could see, perhaps, how people saw me in the bad old days.
If I were a woman, I'd be in love!
As it is, I barely suppressed a "Where can I find you!" before I left his presence.

item.title: Bicycle Show
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Last weekend, I went to a bicycle show.
I had gone last year, and I didn't really have that much fun because I didn't know anyone.
However, we were introduced to Nobillette, an amazing builder. We all saw Blinekey from North Philly so that was good times.
In fact, my SO ordered a custom bicycle!
However, this year was better.
I guess it was because I knew more people there, again mostly through my SO.
I wish I had gone to the band which had tons of Stone Beer. Plus there were tons of parties.
On Sunday, in LA, there was the cyclovia.
So overwhelming!
But I didn't do any of that.
While I was at the bicycle show, I learned a little about what the point was when I looked at some custom parts.
This is because recently, due to poor design, my front derailler broke and I had to get a new one.
At the bicycle show, I saw people who could machine much higher quality parts.
I guess the moral is that even though I didn't get things at first, by hanging around long enough, I was able to learn something.
I'm still not that interested in the mechanics of bicycles at all.

item.title: Kopenhavn I: Arrival
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
With a great friend like Cecilia to greet us, arriving in Kopenhavn was a dream. Of course, she greeted us by waving a set of Danish Flags. Definitely a relief to have a great guide in a new country.
It was so easy to get around because she showed us how to take the train. Of course, we sat in the first seat which gave us a view of the city.
The entire trip, the weather was bearable even without my heavy third upper layer and long underwear--the latter, I never used. The former I used once, and I was too warm. Thus, I was able to actually wear the same clothes I had been wearing in San Diego.
Of course as soon as I got off the subway I saw what I was looking for: bicycles, bicycles, and more bicycles.
Near every door of every shop there were lines of bicycles some of which were so dense looked like stacks and piles of bikes.
Everywhere you looked there was bicycle traffic which was thicker than auto traffic which was great because it allowed people to move more efficiently down the narrow streets.
The most peculiar thing wasn't really the bicycle infrastructure, but how inexpensive and simple it looked.
The main bike path was not, as I had expected, separated from vehicular traffic by walls, but rather it was a step up from the street with a little curb and a step down from the sidewalk. Thus all three modes ran side by side. The bicycle paths were large enough for two bicycles to ride side by side with a third to squeeze by.
The bicycles were mostly rusted and crappy three speeds, but people looked very elegant on them.
Thus, the cost was much lower than expected, and the impact was huge. I was shocked to see how little it would take to make San Diego and the rest of the United States bicycle friendly.
Also, in Kopenhavn, all races and religions were represented on their bicycles. The only thing in common besides their mode was their glamor.
Thus, all the objections based on femininity, or suits, or physical fitness, or age or any other consideration were complete twaddle.
Often cars parked half way on the bike lane and buses unloaded passengers right on the bicycle lanes.
This confusion didn't impede the bicycle traffic in any meaningful way. The oldest ladies to the youngest children--some of them as young as four riding on their own bicycles--smoothly went around any obstruction.
The drivers were incredibly well behaved waiting behind the baby blue rectangle in front of every intersection where there was a possible right hook.
Thus the objection about right hooks was also twaddle.
There were a very few racer types with helmets and spandex who rode much faster on newer, fancier bicycles which puts to rest the whole racing based objection to infrastructure that San Diego has been infected with in the thirty year reign as unofficial "bike expert" Jonas Trees.
All in all, everyone rode bicycles. It was so normal it was almost boring.
There were more bicycles safely accommodated on single lane streets in Kopenhavn as there are for a few hours a month in San Diego during the biggest group rides like Critical Mass. Thus, this puts to the bed the whole myth that bicycles interfere with traffic.
In fact vehicular traffic was light and moved much smoother in San Diego despite the constant lights at every intersection, lack of traffic light "triggers", and the absurdly low speed of twenty miles per hour which confirmed my hypothesis that "net traffic speed" and not "top speed" are more important. "Net traffic speed" was much higher due to the almost total lack of vehicular traffic.
This created a sense of calm and order that I had been craving for such a long time.
Sweet Kopenhavn.
And I saw this in the first half and hour while standing on the street corner...

item.title: Kopenhavn II: Drinking in the Streets
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Kopenhavn II: Drinking in the Streets
Cecilia left us at our hotel for an hour so that we could take naps which we did.
She came back in an hour bearing a six pack which we started drinking right away. Yes public drinking is legal, though I never did see anyone else do it. And when we did it, we got very static from anyone. Nobody seemed to notice anything we did, actually for the most part.
While my sweet SO was out there looking for an ATM, I got permission then hopped on Cecilia's bicycle. Finally, I was riding a bicycle in Kopenhavn for the first time!
It was much tougher than I though as Cecilia has an old, rusty three speed. Also the bicycle lane was really narrow, much tighter than the wide Southern California streets that I was used to. But it wasn't as bad as some people say, and I could get used to it.
It was nice to have so many people passing me.
I rode half a block then walked by bicycle on the sidewalk back to my friend. If I wanted to ride the other way I had to cross the street. Yes, bicycle salmoning was rarely seen during my brief stay, and when they did salmon, they did so on the sidewalk which I guess is two wrongs. Nobody really seemed to mind.
The streets were semi-chaotic. Cecilia said that they were a permissive society which meant no death penalty and surprisingly little crime. Her husband, Marcellus, said, "Nothing bad happens here." Thus shattering more myths on the need for crazy security to be safe.
It seemed like myth after myth was going to be shattered with no end in sight...

item.title: Permanent Tour
item.dc:creator: fredollinger
item.content:encoded:
Permanent Tour
I'm proud to say that I didn't sleep in my bed last night. :)
Yah!
Too bad, I didn't bring a toothbrush and change of underwear.
Yuck!
I'm going to delay the Kopenhavn narrative because I wanted to write about how I felt my life was like a permanent tour.
I may have said this before, but San Diego's great weather and the summer's bright nights make it tough for me to just go home and relax. For some reason, there's always stuff going on, and I want to be part of it rather than miss out.
I loved the excitement of a real city like Philly, but eventually, I realize that the main thing I can do while in the midst of the swirl of lovely humanity is to sit at a cafe and write.
Here I can not write in cafe's; I have tried. I can write at home, but I'm never there.
Before I visited Kopenhavn, I felt burned out and the best thing I liked to do was to come home and to eat dinner while sipping a homebrew and watching comedy.
Now I love going out again. I want to do everything.
I don't know what changed, but I'm happy about it.
For some reason, I'm not worried about being tired all the time, which I am.
I must be jet lagged because last night, I was with some friends, and while cutting lime and cilantro, I almost passed out in the kitchen. The conversation was excellent, but with all my supreme effort, I could not keep my eyes open.
I lay down on the floor and feel asleep. They tried to rouse me but failed so my good friends tossed a blanket on me.
I'm sure a lot of cool stuff happened while I slept.
Man, did I want some of those delicious smelling fish tacos.
I only woke up the next day and rode home to drop off veggies then straight to work. I got here an hour and a half earlier than I need to.
I feel like doing more riding after work as life is now a permanent tour.

item.title: Denmark: Where Everyone Loves My Name
